awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Mathematics at Virginia Commonwealth University
awd_abstract_narration:
The “Mathematics at VCU” Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site is an eight-week research experience for undergraduate students hosted by the Virginia Commonwealth University.  The objectives of this REU Site are to promote early engagement of undergraduate students in research, to involve students in meritorious research programs, to prepare them for the challenges of increasingly complex and information-driven scientific analyses in mathematics, and to inspire them to pursue graduate education. We aim to increase the number and diversity of well-prepared U.S. students who successfully pursue careers in mathematics. Special priority will be given to recruiting applicants who are from institutions that serve underrepresented minorities, who are women, and who are students with limited research opportunities in their home institutions. Students at the early stages of their careers (prior to their sophomore or junior year) will be involved in substantial numbers.  

The REU will provide hands-on research opportunities in several disciplines, including graph theory, mathematical biology, fluid dynamics, analysis, and differential geometry. Projects will involve a computational component and simulations as well as theoretical analysis. Students will be trained on research skills including those used in literature review, understanding ethical issues, using computer software such as LaTeX and Matlab, and oral and written communication of research. We will also hold workshops on undergraduate research, implicit bias, and increasing involvement of women and minorities to facilitate professional development of faculty mentors. Students will work in groups and will stay in touch with their mentors even during the following academic year. The teams will be encouraged to submit manuscripts to professional journals and to present their work at conferences throughout the year.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary focus of this REU program was undergraduate student training and education related to research within mathematics and statistics, focusing on projects in mathematical biology, epidemiology, graph theory and machine learning. In total, 41 students developed and completed their own research projects. The students’ demographic was as follows: 20 males, 20 females, 1 non-binary; 4 African American, 1 American/Alaskan Native, 5 Hispanic; 7 LGBTQ+ community, 3 disabled, and 8 first generation students; 10 students were freshmen, 13 sophomores and 18 juniors. Our online program opened access to students not able to attend face-to-face REU programs. While only 3 students formally declared a disability, the majority of participating students had a health, personal or family circumstance that would prevent them from participating in a traditional face-to-face REU program.

The majority of the projects were interdisciplinary, spanning areas of mathematics and biology, or mathematics and statistics. Two projects in pure mathematics were looking for connections between graph theory and Lie algebras. All students were trained in all aspects of the research and were provided with a research experience that started with creating testable hypotheses and literature search, involved computer aided/numerical simulations and experiments (in Matlab, R, Python, or SAGE), and concluded with a public presentation (written and oral) of the new knowledge gained.  Every student has given at least one conference presentation. In total thus far, the students have given 47 conference presentations, most of which were at national or international conferences.  In addition, there are 14 publications in peer-reviewed journals with several others still in preparation.

We exposed all students to career options for mathematicians including opportunities in academics, industry, and government through career panels every summer. We also increased their awareness of graduate school opportunities, and the preparation needed for graduate school, through a graduate school workshop each summer.  In addition, we had a speaker series in which we brought in a diverse set of speakers in areas closely related to the projects to highlight their careers (including managing a career and family) and to help the students network. In addition, each summer the students were part of the VCU-UOG REU Research Symposium, so the students were able to interact with other math REU students at the University of Guam (UOG). The REU also helped to foster collaboration between mathematicians at VCU, Virginia State University and the University of Guam.
